channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Europe to Lend $105 Billion to Ukraine, Without Touching Russian Funds
item.description: European Union officials wanted to use Russia’s frozen assets to back a major loan to Ukraine. Facing opposition in their own camp, they settled on another way.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: Antonio Costa, center, president of the European Council, said at a news conference early Friday in Brussels that the newly reached deal would “address the urgent financial needs of Ukraine.”

item.title: The Putin Confidant Who Pushed Back Against Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: Dmitri N. Kozak had worked with President Vladimir V. Putin for three decades before quitting in September. His associates described his break with the Russian leader.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Dmitri N. Kozak, then a deputy prime minister of Russia, in 2019. Early in Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, he was a rare voice of dissent.

item.title: Iran’s President Says He Can’t Make ‘Miracles’ to Solve the Country’s Woes
item.description: Amid sky-high inflation, water and energy cuts and prospects for a deal with the U. S. dimming, President Masoud Pezeshkian has apparently thrown up his hands.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran attending a protest in Tehran in June after the U.S. attacks on nuclear sites in Iran.

item.title: Over 1,000 Were Killed in Attack on Camp in Darfur, Sudan, U.N. Says
item.description: A paramilitary attack in April was one of the most brutal of Sudan’s civil war. Now, hunger is spreading as Western aid cuts have reduced U.N. rations.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: People displaced in April after attacks by the Rapid Support Forces on the Zamzam camp in North Darfur, Sudan. A revised toll is over three times as great as earlier estimates.

item.title: At Tokyo Zoo, Visitors Worry Pandas Could Be China’s Next Target
item.description: Pandas have stood for friendship between China and Japan since 1972. But the last two are about to go, and a dispute over Taiwan could get in the way of sending more.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Visitors watching Lei Lei, one of the Ueno Zoo’s two giant pandas, in Tokyo on Tuesday.

item.title: Australia to Crack Down on Hate Speech After Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: New legislation will be drafted to target those who promote violence and to increase penalties for hate speech, the prime minister said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: New South Wales police officers escorting the hearse carrying Rabbi Eli Schlanger after his funeral in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Australia Mourns the Youngest Victim of the Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: Sydney’s devastated Jewish community gathered for the funeral of “Matilda Bee,” an ebullient, smiling 10-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mourner carrying a balloon bearing Matilda’s name and an illustration of a bee, an insect she was known to love, before her funeral in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: Australian Police Detain 7 on Suspicion of Planning a ‘Violent Act’
item.description: No connection has been made between the men and the Bondi shootings, but they are believed to share the gunmen’s “extremist Islamic ideology,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seven men were detained in the police operation in the Liverpool neighborhood of Sydney, Australia, on Thursday.

item.title: Nigeria Closes Lead Recycling Factories Linked to U.S. Car Industry
item.description: Carmakers have known for decades that battery recycling was poisoning people abroad. Nigeria’s crackdown is an effort to catalog the damage.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman, Will Fitzgibbon and Victor Adewale
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Collecting soil samples at True Metals, in Ogijo, Nigeria, on Tuesday.

item.title: Zelensky Appeals to E.U. Leaders for Frozen Russian Funds to Fight War
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said in Brussels, where the leaders had gathered, that without the money, his country would have to reduce its drone production significantly.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, spoke during a news conference on Thursday as part of the European Council meeting in Brussels Thursday.

item.title: French Doctor Sentenced to Life for Fatally Poisoning 12 People
item.description: Frédéric Péchier, an anesthesiologist, was found guilty of poisoning 30 patients, of whom 12 died.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Frédéric Péchier, a former anesthesiologist, outside a courthouse in France this week.

item.title: Trump Revised Chevron’s Venezuela Deal. Maduro’s Oil Trader Profited.
item.description: A firm controlled by a businessman tied to a seized tanker carrying Venezuelan oil has sold millions of barrels from a Chevron-operated oil field.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue outside Venezuela’s state oil company PDVSA headquarters in Caracas.

item.title: Suspect in Bondi Beach Killings Is Charged With Murder and Terrorism
item.description: The Australian authorities said the 24-year-old man, who had been shot by the police, woke from a coma on Tuesday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Yan Zhuang
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: Free Nigerian Students Recount Mass Kidnapping
item.description: Survivors of the St. Mary’s Catholic School abduction in Nigeria recall their harrowing ordeal and release.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Ismail Auwal and Taibat Ajiboye
item.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stephen Samuel.

item.title: Australia Announces Plan to Buy Back Guns in Wake of Bondi Attack
item.description: The program is expected to take hundreds of thousands of firearms out of circulation, the prime minister said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Damien Cave
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, right, at a news conference in Canberra, Australia, on Friday. He announced a nationwide gun buyback plan on the heels of a deadly mass shooting in Sydney last weekend.

item.title: Britain Is Preparing for Attacks on Its Soil. Critics Say It Must Move Faster.
item.description: As military officials sound the alarm over Russian hybrid attacks, the chair of Parliament’s defense committee said the government’s progress on ramping up home defense was “glacial.”
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.media:description: British soldiers during an exercise in Smardan, Romania, in February. In June, the British government published a strategic defense review that said the country must move to “war-fighting readiness.”

item.title: ‘A Singularly Turbulent Time’: Deeper Uncertainty in Store for Global Economy
item.description: A reordering of the rules of trade, set on top of transformational change in technology, demographics and climate, is remaking jobs, politics and lives.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: A furniture factory in Vietnam. Chinese exports are surging not just into Europe but even more sharply into Southeast Asia.

item.title: Before the Massacre, Bondi Suspects Spent Weeks at a Philippine Hotel
item.description: Workers at the budget hotel in the southern Philippines, a region that has long battled Islamist insurgencies, said the two men rarely left their room.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The suspects in the Bondi Beach mass shooting stayed at the GV Hotel in the Philippine city of Davao for most of November, hotel staff said.

item.title: For the First Time, a Former Refugee Will Lead the U.N.’s Refugee Agency
item.description: Barham Salih, who fought against Saddam Hussein’s rule in Iraq and later served as president, was chosen to lead the U.N. High Commission for Refugees.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.media:description: Barham Salih speaking before the United Nations in 2019, when he was the president of Iraq.

item.title: Christian Turner Is Appointed New UK Ambassador to US
item.description: Christian Turner’s appointment comes as the United States and Britain’s relationship is being tested amid a number of foreign policy issues.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Christian Turner, right, will become the next British ambassador to the United States after his predecessor was dismissed over his links to the financier Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: The German Chancellor Betting on America
item.description: Friedrich Merz believes the world needs a stronger Germany. He is still navigating how to do it.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: Putin’s Year-End News Conference Set for Friday
item.description: The annual news conference sets the Kremlin’s tone for the next year and highlights President Vladimir V. Putin’s grip over Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A digital screen in Moscow promoting President Vladimir V. Putin’s year-end televised phone-in and news conference.

item.title: Birthrates Are Falling, but Don’t Blame Dogs in Strollers
item.description: New research suggests that having a pet can actually make people more likely to become parents.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Strolling in Seoul. A South Korean official said young couples were choosing pets over children, but it might not be that simple.

item.title: Peter Arnett, Pulitzer-Winning War Correspondent, Dies at 91
item.description: He won the award for his daring coverage of the Vietnam War for The Associated Press. He went on to cover conflicts for CNN for nearly two decades.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Peter Arnett in Vietnam in 1967. His war coverage there earned him a Pulitzer Prize.

item.title: Israel Approves $37 Billion Deal to Deliver Gas to Egypt
item.description: Israel’s granting of an export permit is the final step to allow the deal, first announced by energy companies in August, to proceed.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: Ofir Berman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Leviathan gas field in the Mediterranean Sea off Israel’s northern coast. Gas is vital to Israel’s economy, typically accounting for about 70 percent of electric power generation.

item.title: Trump’s Claim That Venezuela ‘Stole’ U.S. Oil Fields Sets Off a Nationalist Reaction
item.description: President Trump said the United States wanted to reclaim expropriated oil assets, setting off a nationalist reaction in a country where the resource holds a mythical status.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Derricks in the Maracaibo oil fields of Venezuela in the early 20th century. American oil companies invested millions of dollars in the region, generating profits that flowed to the United States, rather than Venezuela.

item.title: Canada’s Population Shrinks Amid Tightened Immigration
item.description: The government has greatly restricted the number of work and study permits issued to foreigners following an unpopular immigration boom during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: International students and others lining up for buses in Brampton, Canada, where many students and temporary workers from India have settled.

item.title: A Militant’s Transformation
item.description: Ahmed Al-Sharaa, a former Al Qaeda ally, is now president of Syria. We look at his transformation, and whether he can transform his country, too.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Ahmed al-Sharaa, a former rebel commander and now president of Syria.

item.title: Finland Apologizes to China, Japan and South Korea for Racist Gesture
item.description: A Finnish beauty queen was stripped of her crown for a gesture that appeared to mock Asians. Finnish lawmakers copied her, and the prime minister is now trying to defuse the controversy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Johanna Lemola
item.media:description: Prime Minister Petteri Orpo of Finland apologized after lawmakers in the country’s most prominent anti-immigration party and a beauty queen made similar gestures that mocked Asians.

item.title: Two U.K. Police Forces Pledge to Arrest People Who Chant ‘Globalize the Intifada’
item.description: The police in London and Manchester said they would take a “more assertive” approach after the Bondi Beach massacre and a terrorist attack at a British synagogue.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A demonstration in London in support of Palestinians after a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: More Than 2,000 Dinosaur Footprints Are Found in the Italian Alps
item.description: Two hundred million years ago, prosauropods walked the earth. They left something behind.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Victor Mather
item.media:credit: Elio Della Ferrara/Arch. PaleoStelvio (PNS, MSNM, SABAP CO-LC)
item.media:description: Dinosaurs once roamed the earth, including, it seems, in this spot in Italy.

item.title: Bondi Beach Shooting Is a Reminder of ISIS’s Power to Inspire Attacks
item.description: ISIS is too weakened to seize territory, experts said, but its ability to churn out propaganda aimed at provoking violence against the West persists.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Eric Schmitt and Lizzie Dearden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramedics wheel away a wounded man at the scene of the mass shooting in Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: South Africa Arrests Workers Processing U.S. Refugee Applications
item.description: Seven Kenyans were detained for working in the country illegally, officials said. The arrests came amid rising tensions after the United States prioritized white Afrikaners seeking asylum.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: South Africans rallying in support of President Trump outside the U.S. Embassy in Pretoria, South Africa, in February.

item.title: UK Rejoins EU’s Erasmus Student Exchange Program That It Left After Brexit
item.description: The government said it would pay about $760 million to allow young Britons to take part in 2027.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students taking part in the Erasmus exchange program arriving in Gdansk, Poland, in May 2019.

item.title: The Secret Trial of the General Who Refused to Attack Tiananmen Square
item.description: In 1989, Gen. Xu Qinxian defied orders to crush the pro-democracy protests in Beijing. Now, leaked video from his court-martial is on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley

item.title: Grief Mixes With Anger at Funeral of Rabbi Killed in Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: The funeral for Rabbi Eli Schlanger on Wednesday was the first held for one of the 15 people killed in a mass shooting at a Jewish celebration in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners arriving at the Chabad of Bondi on Wednesday for the funeral of Eli Schlanger, in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: On Bali, the Holiday Vibe Masks Memories of a Massacre
item.description: Sixty years ago, half a million Indonesians were killed in anti-Communist purges. On Bali, resorts and clubs were built atop mass graves.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A graveyard on the Indonesian island of Bali where some of the victims of anti-Communist killings in the 1960s are believed to have been buried.

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Team Races Against Time to Save a Tangled Sea Lion in British Columbia
item.description: Experts tracked the sea lion, which had a rope around its neck, for over a month before they were able to catch up to it in Cowichan Bay, Canada.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

item.title: India Charges Pakistan-Based Groups in April Terrorist Attack in Kashmir
item.description: India claims that Pakistan sponsored the terrorists responsible for killing 26 people in the disputed region, an accusation Pakistan denies.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: People mourn one of the victims killed in an attack in Pahalgam, Indian-administered part of Kashmir, in April.

item.title: ISIS and the Bondi Beach Attack
item.description: Australian officials say the suspects were motivated by ISIS. It suggests the group may still have the ability to inspire acts of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at Bondi Beach yesterday.

item.title: Sydney Attackers Motivated by “Islamic State Ideology,” Officials Say
item.description: Investigators said they were also looking into a trip to the Philippines that the father-and-son attackers took last month.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim, Yan Zhuang, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Thomas Fuller
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family of Rabbi Eli Schlanger, who was killed in the attack on Sunday, at a memorial service on Tuesday in Bondi Beach.

item.title: US Boat Strikes Shift to Pacific, Placing Colombia on Watch
item.description: All the strikes in recent weeks have taken place in the Pacific, reflecting Colombia’s role in the drug trade and the feuding between Bogotá and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: Video images posted by the U.S. Southern Command on Monday showed what the U.S. military said were strikes on three narcotrafficking vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Rome’s New Subway Stops Are Part Museum, Part Station
item.description: Part station, part museum, two new subway stops in Rome offer riders the chance to see ancient artifacts unearthed in digging for the stations.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Ancient Roman findings displayed inside of the new subway station Colosseo, in Rome on Tuesday.

item.title: Ukraine Plan Calls For Enhanced Military, With U.S. and European Backup
item.description: The latest proposal is designed to deter future Russian aggression. But Russia is not part of the talks and has shown little willingness to negotiate.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers during a live-fire training exercise at a military training ground in the Dnipro region this month.

item.title: Mark Carney Caught in Canada’s British Spelling Debate
item.description: Some words spelled the British way are emerging in Canadian government documents. A group of language experts say the changes undermine Canada’s identity.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada speaking in Ottawa last week. As a former leader of England’s central bank Mr. Carney spent years exposed to British English.

item.title: U.S. Is Seeking Exemption From a European Climate Law, Officials Say
item.description: Diplomats told E.U. officials that the bloc’s law on methane, a potent greenhouse gas, would hurt American oil and gas companies.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: A liquified natural gas tanker. This year the Trump administration signed a deal with the European Union in which Europe pledged to buy American gas in exchange for tariff relief.

item.title: Rwanda-Backed Militia Says It Will Withdraw From Key City in Congo
item.description: The militia said the withdrawal was intended to give ongoing peace talks with the Congolese government “the maximum chance to succeed.”
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh
item.media:description: Militants fighting with the Congolese government surrendered weapons to the Rwanda-backed M23 militia in Uvira, Congo, on Monday.

item.title: France Passes Welfare Budget Law, Giving Government Rare Win
item.description: Sébastien Lecornu, the third French prime minister in less than a year, succeeded where his two predecessors failed — at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu, at France’s National Assembly on Tuesday, seems to have succeeded after a false start.

item.title: Australia, After a Mass Shooting During Hanukkah, Looks for a Path Forward
item.description: The Bondi Beach massacre has people fearing more anti-Jewish violence — and an Islamophobic backlash. But there are reasons to think stability will prevail.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial service outside the Bondi Pavilion on Tuesday for the victims of the attack in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Trinidad and Tobago Sides With U.S. in Battle Against Venezuela, Military Tool Suggests
item.description: The United States and Trinidad say U.S. Marines installed a radar in Tobago to combat drugs — but this war materiel isn’t designed for operations based at sea or on land.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: A U.S. radar at the A.N.R. Robinson International Airport in Trinidad and Tobago.

item.title: 10-Year-Old Killed in Russia School Stabbing
item.description: The attack appeared to have been inspired by white supremacist ideology, Telegram channels close to intelligence agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Police officers at the entrance of a school in the Moscow region after a stabbing on Tuesday.

item.title: Australia Doubles Down on Gun Control in Wake of Bondi Beach Shooting
item.description: The country has long looked warily at the cycle of gun violence in the United States, where meaningful changes in policy have been rare.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in Sydney on Tuesday. The shooting, which left at least 15 dead and scores of others injured, has forced a hard look at gun control in Australia.
